_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: Frozen Fruit, Juice, and Vegetable Manufacturing

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

Twin City Foods, located in Lake Odessa, Michigan, provides refrigeration for warehousing and distribution of food and related products and services. Twin City Foods? senior management is not only committed to offer superior service, but also maintains a safety and environmental program to promote a safe environment for all its employees and the surrounding communities. Twin City Foods administers safety and environmental policies at the facility to ensure compliance with OSHA?s Process Safety Management (PSM) and EPA?s Risk Management Program (RMP). These programs include forklift safety, hazard communications, lockout/tagout, employee safety manuals, manufacturers documentation, and the Emergency Response Plan.

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

Twin City Foods is located at 1315 Sherman Street in Lake Odessa, Michigan. The refrigeration systems were designed and constructed in accordance with all applicable federal, state, and local regulations.

The facility?s two systems use a total of 31,733 pounds of ammonia to provide refrigeration for warehousing and distribution of food and related products and services. The Processing System uses 24,673 pounds of ammonia, while the Cold Storage System uses 7,060 pounds.  The vessels and compressors are located inside and outside the engine rooms. The condensers are mounted on the roof and all of the evaporators are located in their respective freezer/cold storage areas.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

The Twin City Foods ammonia refrigeration systems have many safety features. Much of the safety of the system is inherent in the policies and procedures that govern the operation of the system.  For example, Twin City Foods operates in accordance with OSHA?s Process Safety Management regulation.

Other safety features of the ammonia refrigeration systems include: ammonia sensors that sound a facility-wide al

arm, an emergency shut down button that kills power to engine room equipment, relief valves on all pressure vessels, and continuous ventilation in the engine room to prevent ammonia explosions.

In addition to the Uniform Mechanical Code, the facility has based its maintenance program on the industry standard: the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration (IIAR) guidelines. In particular, the IIAR Bulletin 110, "Startup, Inspection, and Maintenance of Ammonia Refrigeration Systems? is used at the facility.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

An investigation into the Twin City Foods facility?s accident history revealed that there have been no reportable ammonia releases over the past five years (August 2003 ? August 2008).
 
EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

Twin City Foods has an emergency response plan in effect at the facility. The Emergency Response Plan (Plan) is detailed in the Emergency Planning and Response section of the PSM document, which is maintained at the facility. This Plan was designed to meet the following objectives:

 1.) To save lives.
 2.) To minimize and avoid injuries.
 3.) To protect the environment.
 4.) To minimize property damage.

Twin City Foods maintains a safety committee whose members are the designated emergency coordinators for the facility. The Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures, which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility. This Plan is reviewed and updated at least once per year. This Plan will be reviewed and updated to ensure compliance with the PSM and RMP regulations, as well as to incorporate facility changes due to the renovation of the facility.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) performed in April 10, 2007, generated mitigation measures (recommendations) to improve safety at the Twin City Foods facility located at 1541 W. 27th Street

. The Twin City Foods safety committee has completed several items, including the recommendations, in a continual effort to provide a safe work environment for their employees. These changes include the following items:

1. Continue to train all employees in Process Safety Management and the facility Safety Plan/Programs.

2. Continue to have employee involvement in Safety Plan Development.

3. Continue employee involvement through safety team participation.

4. Continue internal and external safety audits/inspections and implement changes as needed.
